ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Presbycusis
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: 95-year-old patient with a 25-year history of progressive, bilateral, symmetrical sensorineural hearing loss.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Familial Sensorineural Hearing Loss
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Significant family history of hearing loss reported in maternal grandmother, sister, and two children.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To assess hearing sensitivity and configuration given the long history of hearing loss.
To evaluate speech reception thresholds and word recognition ability, especially given complaints of poor clarity.
To screen for retrocochlear pathology, although often difficult in elderly patients.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Audiologic evaluation revealed a bilateral, symmetrical, moderately severe sensorineural hearing loss sloping to severe/profound in the high frequencies. Speech recognition was disproportionately poor (34-40%), indicating significant distortion. Middle ear function was normal.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Bilateral moderately severe SNHL at 250-2000 Hz (approx 50-65 dB HL), sloping to severe (4k Hz) and profound (8k Hz). No air-bone gaps.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: SRT Right 60 dB HL, Left 62 dB HL. WRS very poor: Right 40% at 90 dB HL, Left 34% at 90 dB HL.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.result_summary: Normal Type A tympanograms bilaterally (Right: 0.90 mmho, 45 daPa; Left: 1.20 mmho, -50 daPa).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Threshold and decay testing could not be measured due to excessive artifact.

proposed_items: Consider different Hearing Assistive Technology (HAT) such as captioning for television and telephone

escalation.rationale_short: Patient requires ongoing audiological management including new amplification, HAT, and annual monitoring.
